attachments.title: Typing linear algebra: A biproduct-oriented approach
attachments.text: Interested in formalizing the generation of fast running code for linear algebra applications, the authors show how an index-free, calculational approach to matrix algebra can be developed by...

messages.text: I found an old Maude interface I had done. It's a bit clunky as you have to parse the results from an XML file. Also to properly interface with Julia you'd have to generate Maude code. Are there any mature rewriting software that would be easier to interface with?

messages.text:
What package should I use for checking if two expressions are equal, like the following Mathematica code?
```Equivalent[p && (q || r), (p && q) || (p && r)] // TautologyQ```
Is there a pure Julia library or do all of the symbolic manipulation packages call external libraries?

elements.text: What package should I use for checking if two expressions are equal, like the following Mathematica code?
Equivalent[p && (q || r), (p && q) || (p && r)] // TautologyQ
Is there a pure Julia library or do all of the symbolic manipulation packages call external libraries?

messages.text:
```while tape[1] != 0
    tape[1] -= 1
    while tape[2] != 0
        tape[2] -= 1
        tape[4] += 1
    end
    while tape[4] != 0
        tape[4] -= 1
        tape[2] += 1
        tape[3] += 1
    end
end```

elements.text:
while tape[1] != 0
    tape[1] -= 1
    while tape[2] != 0
        tape[2] -= 1
        tape[4] += 1
    end
    while tape[4] != 0
        tape[4] -= 1
        tape[2] += 1
        tape[3] += 1
    end
end

messages.text: for this one, if you require `tape[1]  < N`, you can write down all of the possible static compilation graphs (and do cool stuff on them) by doing your foldr `N` times

N
times

messages.text:
> tbf, though, is there a reason you'd want loops when doing math (allowing for nontermination)? wouldn't it make more sense to transform to explicit "folds"/recursors? then, you always know what the computation graph looks like, and you can attempt to simplify/optimize it
Yeah, you want to get rid of those things. But for some programs I think it's impossible. MTK's tracing gets a large chunk of codes for which it's possible and you actually want to do it, but not all. Not being able to support `if ... else ... end` and requiring `IfElse.ifelse()` means that a lot of codes don't auto-trace.

elements.text: tbf, though, is there a reason you'd want loops when doing math (allowing for nontermination)? wouldn't it make more sense to transform to explicit "folds"/recursors? then, you always know what the computation graph looks like, and you can attempt to simplify/optimize it

Yeah, you want to get rid of those things. But for some programs I think it's impossible. MTK's tracing gets a large chunk of codes for which it's possible and you actually want to do it, but not all. Not being able to support
if ... else ... end
and requiring
IfElse.ifelse()
means that a lot of codes don't auto-trace.

messages.text: Which uses `IfElse.ifelse`

IfElse.ifelse

messages.text: the problem is that `ifelse` is `Core.ifelse` so you can't add dispatches to it, so we cannot add dispatches to get the symbolic output from it

elements.text: the problem is that
ifelse
is
Core.ifelse
so you can't add dispatches to it, so we cannot add dispatches to get the symbolic output from it

messages.text: Chris Foster has some partial PR in Julia Base trying to fix this up so that it can be `Base.ifelse` and do enough constant prop to be as fast, which would then allow dispatches, but it's not getting full speed.

elements.text: Chris Foster has some partial PR in Julia Base trying to fix this up so that it can be
Base.ifelse
and do enough constant prop to be as fast, which would then allow dispatches, but it's not getting full speed.

messages.text: IfElse.jl is just our hack in the mean time, so that way when Base.ifelse exists as dispatchable we can alias it to there, deprecate the package, and people's syntax will "just work"

elements.text: IfElse.jl is just our hack in the mean time, so that way when Base.ifelse exists as dispatchable we can alias it to there, deprecate the package, and people's syntax will "just work"

messages.text: that'll take at least until Julia v1.7 though

elements.text: that'll take at least until Julia v1.7 though

messages.text: anyone have any recommendations for textbooks/resources for intro symbolics/CAS?

messages.text: If you're looking into term rewriting, Nipkow's "Term Rewriting and All That" is fantastic, imo.

messages.text:
afaik, TRaAT isn't free online. might be able to find at a library (or can buy); otherwise, there are lots of good papers available online, e.g.:
• for a survey, <https://www.cs.tau.ac.il/~nachum/papers/taste-fixed.pdf>
• for some background (and then Knuth-Bendix completion): <https://www.researchgate.net/publication/220460160_An_Introduction_to_Knuth-Bendix_Completion>
• implementation of matching via finite automata: <https://www.semanticscholar.org/paper/Adaptive-Pattern-Matching-Sekar-Ramesh/e563d357c7094edadde3bd948747d6e0fce148de>
